article.title: Simultaneous low- and high-mass star formation in a massive protocluster: ALMA observations of G11.92-0.61

choices: The distribution of different molecules in G11.92-0.61
ALMA 1.05 mm continuum image of G11.92-0.61 revealing numerous compact sources
Spitzer infrared image of G11.92-0.61 showing the Extended Green Object
A simulation of competitive accretion model for high-mass star formation

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from comparing the SMA 12CO(3-2) contours with the ALMA 1.05 mm continuum image in Figure 2a?
choices: All the newly detected millimeter continuum sources are driving molecular outflows.
The MM1 outflow is significantly less collimated than those from the new low-mass cores.
At least two of the new ALMA sources (MM6 and MM7/MM9) are also driving molecular outflows.
The ATLASGAL 870 Î¼m clump is misaligned with the outflow activity in G11.92-0.61.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 demonstrate about the relationship between the newly detected millimeter continuum sources and molecular line emission?
choices: N2H+ (3-2) emission closely traces the morphology of the millimeter continuum for all new sources.
Only MM8 and MM10 are associated with molecular line emission that is morphologically similar to the dust continuum.
CH3OH 9-1-80 (Class I maser line) is predominantly associated with the massive protostar MM1.
All new sources have compact molecular line emission associated with them, but at different velocities.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 tell us about the location of the newly detected low-mass cores in G11.92-0.61?
choices: The new cores are evenly distributed throughout the clump, with no preference for distance from MM1.
Most of the low-mass cores are found near the cluster center, within 0.1 pc of MM1.
The low-mass cores are preferentially located in the outer reaches of the accretion reservoir, with a median projected separation of ~0.17 pc from MM1.
There is a clear correlation between core mass and distance from MM1, with more massive cores located further away.
The free-fall timescale of a core based on its density.
The gas mass of a source based on its observed millimeter continuum emission.
The momentum of a molecular outflow based on integrated intensity and velocity range.
The spectral index of a source from its flux density at two different wavelengths.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Table 4 show regarding the outflows in G11.92-0.61?
choices: The MM1 outflow is significantly more energetic and massive than those driven by the newly detected low-mass cores.
The MM6 outflow has the highest mass outflow rate of all the outflows detected in G11.92-0.61.
The MM7/MM9 outflow is not detected in 12CO(3-2), but only in H2CO emission.
All the outflows have very similar properties, regardless of the mass of the driving source.
